Hey, keep it down over there. I'm
recording a video. Thank you. Some

people. Hey, everyone. I'm Alex. Thanks
for clicking, and welcome to this lesson

on: "Ten Common Imperatives with the
Verb 'Keep'". So, in this lesson, I will

give you some useful language that you
can use in conversation; and what you

can recognize when you see it in film,
if you hear it in a song, or in a series

that you're watching. So, this is all
very useful language. "Keep" is one of

the most common verbs that English
speakers use to make commands and

imperatives, as you will see shortly.
So, first: "Keep going". So, "to keep

going" means that you are encouraging
someone to continue or to keep moving

forward. So, this can have a couple of
different contexts. Number one: If

you're in a line, and someone in front
of you is playing on their phone, and

the line is moving; they're not moving —
you can say: "Excuse me. Keep going".

Like: "Keep moving". Okay? Like: "Don't
stop; keep mo-... keep going; keep

moving". You can also be watching sports
on TV and be yelling at your TV, for,

you know... if someone is playing
soccer, and they're getting closer to

the net, you can say: "Keep going, keep
going, keep going!" Don't stop; keep

moving forward; keep continuing to do
what you are doing.

Next: "Keep trying". So, this means:
Continue making an effort. You are

probably familiar with this one. It just
means: Don't stop doing what you're

doing; keep making an effort. Another
imperative with "keep" that has a very

similar meaning is: "Keep at it". So,
"keep at it" — it means: Don't give up;

continue making an effort. So, these two
are linked: "Keep trying" or "Keep at

it". Okay? "Keep trying. You're not
going to improve on the piano or the

guitar if you just give up. Keep trying;
keep at it — you will improve." Just

like with your studying English. "Keep
at it. Keep trying. Don't give up; you

will get it." Next... the next two are
actually very similar as well. "Keep

quiet". Okay? So, this means: Stay
silent. If you are a parent, this is a

very useful imperative. I have nothing
to say or nothing to add to that. Yeah,

just... I say it a lot. Probably too
much. All right? So: "Keep quiet",

means, like: Stay silent. "Daddy's on
the phone. Okay? So, keep quiet". Or:

"Keep it down". Now, "Keep it down" —
this means to keep the volume down; keep

the volume low, or to stay silent;
become silent. "Keep it down" means

become completely silent; or, like:
"Reduce the volume, please." Okay?

"You're too loud; keep it down". All
right.

Next: "Keep it to yourself". Okay? So,
this means: Don't tell anyone. Shh. It's

a secret. Okay? So, if your friend comes
up to you and says: -"Hey. Did you hear

about Barbara? Pss, pss, pss, pss, pss,
pss, pss." -"What? Barbara?" -"Shh, shh,

shh, shh, shh, shh. Keep it to yourself,
okay? Don't tell anyone." Now, this

imperative can also be a little rude if
you are, you know... talking to someone

or someone is talking to you, and
they're very excited to tell you

something, but you don't care about what
they're saying or you don't want to hear

what they're saying — either because you
have no patience or there isn't enough

time — you can say: "Yeah, yeah, yeah,
yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. Keep it to

yourself. Nobody wants to hear this
right now. Okay? So, just keep it to

yourself." You keep it inside your, you
know... inside your mind, inside your

heart. No one needs to hear this or no
one wants to hear this right now. So:

"Shh. Keep it to yourself" — it's a
secret. Or: "Keep it to yourself" —

nobody cares. It's a little rude, but
it's possible. Okay, next. Where are we?

Ah, there. "Keep your chin up. Okay. So,
how... and what kind of body language do

you use if you are feeling negative, or
down, or sad? Right? Some people, if

you're sad, your chin is probably down;
your eyes are looking at the ground, and

you're not feeling great. If someone
tells you to "keep your chin up", it

means: Try to stay positive. Okay? So,
for example, if you recently got out of

a relationship, and your friends are
trying to encourage you, and you're

saying: "I will never find someone. Oh,
Stephanie. I love you and miss you so

much, Stephanie, why?" And your friends
say: "Buddy, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa,

whoa. Keep your chin up. Okay? Try to
stay positive. She wasn't good for you.

You can do better than Stephanie. In
fact, don't think about Stephanie

again." Okay? I'm going to go call
Stephanie now. I don't know a Stephanie.

So: "Keep your chin up" — try to stay
positive; it's not the end of the world.

Okay? Maybe Stephanie will come back one
day.

So, next. Very common. If you are
watching this and we are still in the

midst of a pandemic, regardless of, you
know... when you're... when you're

watching this, and if COVID-19 is still
making the world a different place right

now: "Keep your distance". This means:
Stay away. So, here in Canada, the rule

is to keep a two-meter distance from
people who are, you know... keep

social... keep your social distance
means stay away a certain, you know...

length of time; not, like, length of
time. Length of space. Yeah. You know

what I mean. "Keep your distance" — stay
away. And, finally: "Keep the change".

So: "Keep the change" means: Don't give
me the change; you keep it. If you pay

for something and that thing costs 50
cents — you only have one dollar —

that's a lot of change, actually.
That's, like, 100%. Okay? Profit. So, if

it costs 50 cents; you only have one
dollar — you say: "Yep. Here's a dollar.

I'm going to buy this" — if it's a bag
of chips, or a chocolate bar, or

something — and you say: "That's okay.
Keep the change." Okay? Don't give me

back the extra 50 cents that you're
supposed to give me for, you know... the

thing I just bought. All right? And if
you have ever seen the movie: "Home

Alone", you might remember the line in
the movie, where they're watching... or

Kevin McAllister is watching this
gangster movie and the guy, like, starts

shooting the guy on the outside. And
once he, you know... kills him... think

it's Snakes. Snakes is the guy that
shoots. Or Snakes is the guy that

shoots. Anyway, he goes: "Keep the
change, you filthy animal." Right?

"Filthy" means, like, dirty. So, like:
You dirty animal. Anyway, go watch:

"Home Alone". It's an all-time classic,
even though it has elder abuse and other

problematic aspects to it, but it's a
holiday classic. Haven't shown it to my

kids. Not sure if I will anytime soon.
They're a little young for the violence

and the stuff. Back to "keep". That's
what we were talking about, right?

So, one more time to review; and this
time, I want you to practice the

pronunciation. Put your heart and soul
into it. Let me feel you commanding it

with the imperatives that I'm going to
give you. So, repeat after me. I don't

care if you're on the bus. Okay? Just do
it. Just do it; scare people. Maybe

you'll... you'll make a friend. So:
"Keep going", "keep trying", "keep at

it", "keep it up", "shh, keep quiet",
"keep it down", "keep it to yourself",

"keep your chin up". This is your chin,
right? "Keep your chin up", "keep your

distance", "keep the change, you filthy
animal". Not you; I was just quoting the

movie. So, please don't take that the
wrong way. And you know what? Because

this is a long video... did I do: "Keep
it up"? I'm not sure if I did. So, just

in case I didn't: "Keep it up" means to
continue in the same way. So, if you're

doing well or someone is doing well at
something, and you want to encourage

them to keep going in the same way, you
say: "Keep it up. Good job". Continue in

the same way. And just like you're
keeping it up and... and you're...

bababa. Give me a moment. Brain reset.
There we go. Just like you're keeping it
